charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: I am walking 300k steps minimum because they were amazing support to us
pageSummaryWhy: they were amazing support to us
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising efforts! 

In 2019 I went through a cancer scare and was told I would have to have a full masectomy on one side. Whilst thankfully I only had to have a slightly more complex lumpectomy I went through the whole process initially deciding what type of reconstructure, going over differant time frames and outcomes and it was a very scary period. 

Macmillan Cancer Support nurses were amazing throughout. They provided myself and my wife amazing support and advice. They called me randomly during my 2 week decision period to check in on me and really went above and beyond what I thought they did.

We would love to raise some money to say thanks to them for everything they do for families going through a cancer scare. Their support can never be thanked enough but we can try.


t Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.

pageSummary: In March my wife and I will be doing 300,000 steps because They were incredible during my wife's cancer scare
pageSummaryWhat: In March my wife and I will be doing 300,000 steps
pageSummaryWhy: They were incredible during my wife's cancer scare
story:
We cannot thank macmillan enough for everything they have done for our family.  In December 2019 my wife found a breast lump that resulted in her having a partial mastectomy. This is one of the most frightening things we've went through as a couple and we would not have coped anywhere near as well if it wasn't for macmillan.

Now that my wife is fit and healthy we want to do whatever we can to thank macmillan and so any donations or post shares will go a long long way.

pageSummary: Walking because of the great work and support they provide.
pageSummaryWhy: of the great work and support they provide.
story:
4 years ago Daddy received his diagnosis of lymphoma. In April 2020, he started his treatment. As a keen footballer for Creggan and Antrim in his day, with a spot of refereeing along the way, sport and fitness have always been very important to him. To show his appreciation and gratitude for the tremendous support that Macmillan has given him, we will be walking virtually from Creggan to Croke Park throughout the month of March in keeping with PHA COVID guidelines to raise awareness.

All donations to Macmillan are hugely appreciated.

The Maguire Family

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: We are fundraising because they have helped our family.
story:
Pat was an amazing woman, incredibly kind and gentle. She lived a full life often living alone but had lots of friends and family around her.  She lived to the wonderful age of 88 (two fat ladies - she was an avid bingo player and card shark).  She lived 62 years in Leeds until she retired from the tailoring trade when she moved to Harrogate to spend the next 24 years of her retired life.  She filled her life with lunch clubs, knit and natter groups and over 70’s keep fit.  She will be joining the bingo club in Heaven and finding other card sharks to have fun playing for pennies.  

She developed memory problems in the last 5 years of her life and for the last 10 months she lived in Lothian House, a care home specialising in the care of Dementia patients in Spennymoor.  She developed Lung Cancer in October 2020 which eventually ended her life. 

She would love you to donate to Macmillan Cancer Support in her memory as they were just wonderful helping her through those final difficult weeks.
title: In Memory of Pat
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Pat Briggs
Name: In Memory of Pat

pageSummary: Running 300KM in March because of how they've helped my Mum.
pageSummaryWhy: of how they've helped my Mum.
story:
As some will already know, my Mum was diagnosed with Breast Cancer in November 2020. This was obviously some unwanted news to come on top of the terrible year that us, and countless other people around the world have gone through because of the pandemic. 

My Mum has now gone through two major surgeries and still has a long road of possible Chemotherapy/Radiotherapy ahead of her, but I have been amazed by how she has dealt with her situation. I've said to numerous people when they've asked me how she's doing that she is handling this a million times better than I ever would. From the day she found out that she had cancer she has taken a positive outlook towards the situation. She hasn't dwelled on it and asked why her, she has just got on with it and done everything she's needed to do.

Nothing I can do will be anywhere close to what she's been through, but when I mentioned doing this to her and asked her what charity she'd want it done for she reminded me of the times when the Macmillan nurses at Worthing and St Richards hospitals had been there for her, and been on hand to answer any questions she's had and put her mind at ease about the worrying things she was going through. She said that she wanted it done for them to support their ability to give other people the same treatment and advice that they gave her.


Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Timothy was a beloved husband to the late Yvonne, father to Elizabeth as well as a much loved son, brother, uncle, nephew and friend. His battle with a rare cancer began in 2018 at which point he was given just 6-8 months to live. Following treatment at Manchester Royal Infirmary and The Christie hospital, he fought hard against the illness, undergoing many gruelling rounds of chemotherapy until his cancer stabilised. Sadly, Timothy passed away in February after almost three-years of defying the odds.

Tim was a hard working man from the north of England. A British Gas worker for almost 40 years, he travelled around the country with his work and was a credit to his family who were always so proud of all he achieved. Passionate about music and film throughout his life, he enjoyed seeing live music whenever he had the opportunity and had an enviable film collection which he continued to grow throughout his life. He loved sport too and would enjoy seeing his beloved Manchester United football club whenever he had the opportunity.  

At the end of his life, Tim was supported by Macmillan.

pageSummary: Challenging ourselves during the month of March because We see the difference Macmillan make every day
pageSummaryWhat: Challenging ourselves during the month of March
pageSummaryWhy: We see the difference Macmillan make every day
story: Thanks for supporting our fundraising. As a team, the 8 of us have decided that we want to give something back during March. Our employer, Aviva, have a partnership with Macmillan Cancer Support  and everyday we see the difference Macmillan makes to people’s lives. We will be doing a variety of challenges during the month:  50 miles walking 50 miles running (Patti & Alastair), 250 miles cycling, 50 miles running (Neil), 250k cross trainer, 310k steps (Matt), sea swim every day (no wetsuit allowed!), 310k steps (Paula), 150 miles running, 310k steps (Paul), 500 miles cycling (Steven).  We are doing this because everyone in some way has been impacted by this awful disease  and people don’t stop getting cancer just because there’s pandemic, this support is much needed and our activities will truly challenge us, so please donate! Here’s a few words about the charity:  At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. story:
Hello! My name is Derek Morrice. I am the wrong side of 50 and overweight. In December my mum was diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic breast cancer. Seeing how well she has been treated and supported by Macmillan nurses, it has prompted me to help raise money and help highlight the importance of everything they do. I may even lose some weight in the process! 

I have given myself the challenge (with a little push from my mum!) to walk from my house in Boat of Garten to her house in Aviemore. This is approximately 5miles, 20 times in 21 days! 

Please donate whatever you can however small it all helps towards the charity for Macmillan cancer support.

pageSummary: March madness 10 +10 challenge because it is time to do my bit!
pageSummaryWhy: it is time to do my bit!
story:
It is my birthday on the 1st of April. Instead of people giving me presents that I really do not need,  I wanted to do something that would make a difference. I have seen so many times how cancer has affected my friends, family and work colleagues. It is a cruel and selfish disease that leaves everyone vulnerable. So this is my chance to make a difference.

Therefore I pledge to complete 10,000 metres of rowing and 10,000 steps every single day for the whole of March. It is going to hurt but it will be worth it. Please support this important cause and spur me on.

Thanks, everyone in advance! 

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. pageSummaryWhy: Cancer hurt out friend and we want to help others
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page  

We have chosen to make a donation to this charity in memory of Anis due to the battle he fought over many years against cancer. We remember Anis as the ‘Tunisian Mountain’, a gentle giant with a kind and loving nature.

Anis will be with us in mind & spirit and we will remember the beautiful young family he leaves behind Angelika, Ilias and Melina; his mother and siblings.

Thank you Anis for being YOU.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: I am running 100k in March because they fund vital cancer services
story:
The name Macmillan has been familiar to many of us, we see it on the adverts, we see friends raising money for them.... for our family we got to understand more about them when they supported my Dad with his cancer in 2012. We will always be grateful for the care, compassion and support they gave us and him.

This introduction to Macmillan later lead me to taking up a voluntary counselling role with Macmillan. Later becoming a member of the palliative care team and part of the wider cancer services team at a local hospital.

I now know that Macmillan is way more than helplines, leaflets.... Macmillan fund nurses, doctors, psychological support workers, counsellors, physiotherapists, HCA’s, dieticians as well as providing vital physical resources.

Cancer services will suffer enormously if vital fundraising continues to suffer as it did in 2020..

So this year I am setting myself challenges to help raise funds for Macmillan! Starting with my first challenge 100k in March! Now if you know me, you know I actually really don’t like running! You’ll also know I’m slow as hell!! So this will be a real challenge for me!!! I’d love some support and obviously if you can a donation that would be fabulous! Remember, even small donations add up to make a difference!!

I’ll keep you posted with progress (lucky you!) as well as sharing more information about Macmillan in the coming months!!

Thanks for your support!!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Set up on behalf of Rob Waite, a short message from him:

On the 11th
of March I will be 49 years old, so I will be running 49 miles in 49 hours with 49lbs (22.2kg) in a rucksack/Bergan on my back.  I am doing this (Beside being an Idiot) for my sister in law who did a heap of voluntary work for Macmillan cancer charity and continued to do so whilst also receiving treatment for her own cancer. Sally passed away December 2020. Rachel and I will continue to support her charity in her Memory. Macmillan cancer support is one of the largest British charities and provides specialist health care, information and financial support to people affected by cancer. It also looks to the social, emotional and practical impact cancer can have and campaigns for better cancer care.   Ways to donate to Macmillan - Macmillan Cancer Support

I will also run for Care of Police Survivors (COPS)as my daughter is a serving police officer and let’s be honest them dudes have it tough right now putting up with all the Covid restrictions on top of their normal role.

Care of Police Survivors (COPS) is a charity that supports the families of police officers and staff who have lost their lives on duty. COPS is almost entirely funded through donations from the police community and public. If you’d like to support their work, why not make a donation, visit their shop or raise money for them? Donate - COPS

(ukcops.org)

 If anyone wishes to join me for a virtual leg please let me know via the just giving page.

pageSummary: I am trying to raise money because They have been truly amazing
pageSummaryWhat: I am trying to raise money
story:
In January my cousin Chris Jones got taken to hospital with a collapsed lung. Whilst he was treated for this his bloods were tested, unfortunately and shockingly he was diagnosed with a rare form of Blood Cancer called Burkitts Lymphoma. He is had his first round of chemotherapy but must remain in hospital for four months while he receives his intense daily treatment plan. When he recieved the news of his condition he was fully supported by Macmillan. They offered lots of help, support and advice to Chris and his family as they continue to do so making his journey personal and stress free as they possibly can!

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Running 150k for the whole of March
pageSummaryWhat: Running 150k for the whole of March
story: The impact of Covid-19 has cut the research budget for BHF in half. If 2020 has taught us anything, it’s that research works. 60 years ago, 7 out of 10 heart attacks were fatal. Now, 7 out of 10 people survive. Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. By supporting me in raising money, you are helping to fund research into a cure for heart disease; a condition affecting nearly 1 million people in the UK. You are helping to fund research into congenital heart disease so that one day, every baby can be saved. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now. Together we can make sure we have more time with the people we love.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate and sweets in March because I want to challenge myself to eat healthier snacks
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate and sweets in March
pageSummaryWhy: I want to challenge myself to eat healthier snacks
story:
I have generally been trying really hard to be healthier so far in 2021. BUT - the place where this has been coming apart a bit is the snack cupboard! So much time at home has meant more chocolate and unhealthy snacks than usual, and are not sustainable in the long term. So, please help me to stay off it this month by paying me not to do it...

Giving up chocolate and sweets is one of the best things you can do for your heart and circulation. Heart health is something we probably take too much for granted, but is something we literally cannot live without. 

Covid 19 has put people with heart and circulatory diseases at greater risk than ever - the impact of the pandemic has forced British Heart Foundation to cut its research in half, so please donate to help them fight heart disease and other vascular conditions.

pageSummaryWhat: We are going without chocolate for the full month
pageSummaryWhy: A healthy beating heart is important
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: Hello! Greg & I are both doing Dechox for the BHF. because Their research is a matter very close to us...
pageSummaryWhat: Hello! Greg & I are both doing Dechox for the BHF.
pageSummaryWhy: Their research is a matter very close to us...
story:
Greg & I have decided to do the dechox for March this year. The BHF provide life saving research which helps combat and support those with debilitating and life altering heart conditions. This is exceptionally close to my heart (lol pun unintended). 

I have a life long heart condition in which probably would not have been able to be successfully cared for had it not been for amazing research and staff from the BHF and the Golden Jubilee in Glasgow.

We are the biggest foodies out and absolutely love biscuits, chocolate and fizzy juice (including diet) which a lot will know I can go through 24 cans of diet irn bru in 3 days (no joke)! 

So we are going 31 days without ANY of the above. Please donate what you can. The BHF budget has been halved due to COVID, so every little helps.

Thanks for reading and keep well.

All our love

Corinne & Greg x

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Giving up chocolate (yet again!) because No one should have to worry about heart disease.
pageSummaryWhy: No one should have to worry about heart disease.
story:
You probably already know that I lost my Dad to heart disease in 2013. He'd just been approved for a pacemaker. Within 24 hours of receiving his appointment letter he was dead. He was only 63. It was sudden and unexpected, and we didn't get to say goodbye. 

Situations like ours need to be eradicated. It's a horrible place to be in, and I wouldn't wish it on anyone. This is why I'm Dechoxing again to raise money for such a vital organisation.

The coronavirus pandemic is the biggest challenge the British Heart Foundation faced in their 60 year history.

This has led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. Which is a major blow to the people suffering from heart disease. 

So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help them keep up the pace of progress.

My willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need them most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers.

For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

ProfileWhy: No one should have to worry about heart disease.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: No chocolate for a month 😬 because I’m doing this for my health and in memory of Dad
pageSummaryWhy: I’m doing this for my health and in memory of Dad
story:
I fear I’m addicted to chocolate.  If it’s in the house I eat it 😬.  Then I try and buy or make ‘healthy’ chocolate, and then I eat it all too.  Even if I’m making a healthy smoothie I add cocoa powder. So, for a whole month I’m going to try not to eat any chocolate at all.  If I manage it, it will be the first month of adulthood with no chocolate. 

In addition I won’t be eating any sweets or drinking any fizzy pop (although this is easy for me, it’s chocolate that is the challenge). So I’m also giving up and cake or biscuits to make it a proper challenge for me. 

If you have a spare £1 for the pot it all helps and will help me stay on track  thank you  x

Wish me luck!

Raising funds for British Heart Foundation  in memory of my dad, David. Love you dad xxxx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I would like to raise money for the BHF any way I can. After my mum passed away suddenly in October 2020 from hypotensive heart disease this charity is especially close to my heart ♥️ 

BHF is the UK’s leading heart charity funding research into heart disease. So every penny counts, it all adds up so thank you in advance

This will be an extremely hard challenge for me as I am a chocoholic and I eat it every day!! So wish me luck! 

Here’s to the next 31 days chocolate free 😬

Let’s #DECHOX 

xxx

story: The sad passing of one of our colleagues has been a shock to us all and may of made us all realise how short life can be. Due to the nature of Sean‘s passing and the support Sean’s family want to provide for the British Heart Foundation the team have decided at MIA Train Station to walk 12,500 steps a day throughout the whole march to raise funds for this worth while cause. Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

pageSummary: I am doing this in memory of my mum because I want to try and make a difference
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing this in memory of my mum
pageSummaryWhy: I want to try and make a difference
story:
Some of you will know I've undertaken this challenge before but this time its slightly different, I'm giving up not only chocolate,  but sweets and fizzy drinks too. I'm doing this as before in memory of my mum. She was the most wonderful mum a girl could ask for, this years been a tough one to get through, and I sometimes wonder what she would have thought of it all!! 

I know money is tight for alot of people right now but theses charity's need help to survive. Please give what you can to support me, believe me I'm gonna need all the support I can get!!

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: Walking 12500 steps a day in March because See my story
pageSummaryWhat: Walking 12500 steps a day in March
story: The sad passing of one of our colleagues has been a shock to us all and may of made us all realise how short life can be. Due to the nature of Sean‘s passing and the support Sean’s family want to provide for the British Heart Foundation the team have decided at MIA Train Station to walk 12,500 steps a day throughout the whole march to raise funds for this worth while cause. Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

story:
Hi I’m Jules and if anybody knows me they will know that I love chocolate but am definitely more of a crispaholic ! I have done the Dechox Challenge a number of times before so this year I thought I would make it a little harder by giving up the three C’s. The three C’s being Chocolate, Cakes and Crisps ! Crisps are actually my worst downfall more so than chocolate so will definitely be a struggle. Beechy my partner will also be joining me on this challenge. He’s given up Guinness (well, until the pubs open again ) and said he’d support me and give up the three C’s too. So please support us in helping raise funds for the BRITISH Heart Foundation. Our challenge will last for the whole of March.

  The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. pageSummary: I am raising as much money on Twitch because of the support they’ve given me and my family!
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising as much money on Twitch
pageSummaryWhy: of the support they’ve given me and my family!
story:
Thank you for visiting my funding page!

I am raising money for the British Heart Foundation through a charity stream on Twitch.

The reason being is because...my fathers life was massively impacted since the day he was born in 1966. He was born with a hole in his heart in which he had to proceed to have a “Hole Repair” which required his Sternum and ribs to be broken to fix it in order for him to survive.

A heart transplant is an operation to replace a damaged or failing heart with a healthy heart from a donor who's recently died.

In 1997, he had many cardio versions which is :

a treatment which aims to get your abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia) back to a normal pattern. 

It’s done by sending electric signals to your heart through electrodes placed on the chest. 

Cardiac ablation is a procedure to scar or destroy tissue in your heart that's allowing incorrect electrical signals to cause an abnormal heart rhythm. Diagnostic catheters are threaded through blood vessels to your heart where they are used to map your heart's electrical signals.

Then, in 2004. He had 2 human valve transplants which is :

Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is a minimally invasive procedure to replace a narrowed aortic valve that fails to open properly (aortic valve stenosis). In this procedure, doctors insert a catheter in your leg or chest and guide it to your heart.

So...as you can see he has had a rough life and fought through every single second of it like a warrior!

We have had continuous support from the “British Heart Foundation” and they have helped us all throughout the tough journey...

This is where the BRNZYARMY and the Twitch Community come into place to support me, my family and the British Heart Foundation.

With your help, we can hit this goal and give our huge thanks to this amazing charity!

#BRNZYARMY

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. We’re raising money for the British Heart Foundation and would be so grateful for your support. 


The girls and I are doing the 🍫 Dechox again this year in aid of the British Heart Foundation ❤️

Starting tomorrow we are giving up chocolate for the whole month of March...as well as sweets AND fizzy drinks!

Please help encourage us if you see us and if you could spare a few pounds it would be very much appreciated ❤️

(Encourage does include knocking the chocolate from our hands/mouths! 😉😂)

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Please donate if you can!❣️

pageSummary: I am doing the ultimate dechox because too many people die each year from heart disease
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing the ultimate dechox
pageSummaryWhy: too many people die each year from heart disease
story:
Anyone who know me will know this is the ultimate sacrifice and it will not be easy for a chocoholic like me to give up chocolate, crisps and fizzy drinks for a day never mind the full month of March

But sadly on 18th February 2021 I lost a friend and colleague Mary Richford due to her having a heart attack caused by undiagnosed diabetes. Mary had just celebrated her 50th birthday and it has came as a shock to everyone who knew her. 

I am wanting to raise funds and awareness in her memory because we must beat heartbreak forever 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: We are giving up chocolate AND sweets this March because some hearts need a little extra love!
pageSummaryWhat: We are giving up chocolate AND sweets this March
pageSummaryWhy: some hearts need a little extra love!
story:
The British Heart Foundation is an amazing charity close to our hearts (pun intended!) and during the multiple lockdowns, Dan and I have eaten far more than our own weight in sweet treats...oops! So what better way to kick ourselves into action to cut out the treats and do good for our own hearts and bodies, than to cut out the sweet treats and raise some money for charity at the same time! It's a win-win situation! 

So please, if you can donate anything at all we would be incredibly greatful - it will really spur us on and you'll be helping a fantastic charity continue their life saving work. 

Thank you!

Abbie & Dan

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

From the British Heart Foundation:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
We lost my wonderful Grandpa last year and I wasn't able to attend the funeral in person or say a proper goodbye so I want to do this in memory of him. He underwent a number of life saving heart operations and this allowed us to have so many more years with him, which makes the British Heart Foundation a charity close to our hearts (excuse the pun). If you know me you know I LOVE chocolate, and anything chocolate flavoured is my first choice, if I can include it for breakfast, lunch and dinner (and in between) I will! SO while to some this may seem an easy challenge for me, who has been comfort eating my way through the last year on anything chocolate related, this is going to be really hard (I don't remember going a day without it) ... and let's face it my knees would never stand up to a sponsored run! Hopefully at the end of the month I will also have a healthier heart! I'll be very grateful for any and everything you can give.

................................................................

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am going to try my absolute best because It’s a fantastic charity helping others.
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to try my absolute best
pageSummaryWhy: It’s a fantastic charity helping others.
story:
I’m doing this challenge as I think it will be good for me, it’s going to be a gargantuan challenge and I want to see how I do with it, I definitely want to give it a try, “better to have tried than not at all. “

Completing a few days would be great but for longer even more awesome! 

Its a chocolate give up this time round.  I can’t promise I will complete it, I think the less pressure I give myself the better. I’m going to use the approach , ‘I will see how I get on. ‘

The best incentive is it raises money for an absolutely brilliant cause. A thank you for all the useful research and articles that I have read in the past to keep us informed. 

Support me with words and socially distanced company :0)  if you fancy joining me in donating, that would be lovely and I thank you. 🙏 I will be donating at the end of the challenge.

I will update with posts, some may be funny... or not lol  😂 you can encourage me on my way, you may even get me through some more days 😃

Take care and stay safe 

Carol x
title: 31 Days No Chocolate Gargantuan Challenge
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: 31 Days No Chocolate Gargantuan Challenge
ProfileWhat: I am going to try my absolute best
ProfileWhy: It’s a fantastic charity helping others.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Somewhat unbelievably, 2021 marks ten years since we lost my Dad.

With charities in need of funds now more than ever, I thought it would be a good opportunity to do something positive in Dad’s memory and help raise a few pennies for the British Heart Foundation at the same time.

So I’ve set myself the challenge to run 1200km by doing 100km every month in 2021.

With January and February under my belt I know this won’t be easy, so any small donation you can give in support of this very worthy cause would really help to keep me going!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: I am giving up the thing I love most for March because I want to help the BHF and my family
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up the thing I love most for March
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help the BHF and my family
story:
Over the past year both my mum and sister have discovered troubling heart conditions. I’d like to do my bit to help raise funds to ensure that vital research, which may help them, continues. By giving up something I love for March (Chocolate), I hope to raise at least £100 towards the life changing research.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. story:
Anyone who knows Amelia will know her love for all things sweet. She has been wanting to do a challenge for a good cause and when we came across this, it felt perfect. She will be giving up chocolates and sweets for the month of March to raise money for the British Heart Foundation. Sadly our family has a long history of heart disease which makes this even more pertinent. If you can spare £1 it will take her a long way toward achieving her target. ❤️

pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate, sweets & fizz in March because BHF is a great charity and helps so many people!
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate, sweets & fizz in March
pageSummaryWhy: BHF is a great charity and helps so many people!
story:
I would have loved to do a walking/cycling challenge for March to raise money for a charity, however for those of you that know my current back/hip/leg issues, you will know that getting a mere 10,000 steps a day for me is already a challenge. 

So! I have decided to give up chocolate, sweet things and fizzy drinks. Yes, most people will be shocked I'm even thinking of this as I have such a sweet tooth, but its a challenge I am willing to accept! I know its not a huge challenge, but its something that I hope can contribute. 

This means no chocolate, cakes, biscuits, cookies, candy or fizzy drinks for a whole month! 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Month 3 of challenge 2021 and taking a break from the physical to get my diet in gear! 

Found during the lockdowns I have been relying on chocolate to boost my mood & deal with stress, however, overall it is actually having a negative effect on my mind & body so this is a great opportunity for a reset!

In all honesty I am more scared of this one than the 100km bike ride.....

Wish me luck!!

Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story: The sad passing of one of our colleagues has been a shock to us all and may of made us all realise how short life can be. Due to the nature of Sean‘s passing and the support Sean’s family want to provide for the British Heart Foundation the team have decided at MIA Train Station to walk 12,500 steps a day throughout the whole march to raise funds for this worth while cause. Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate for the whole of March because they desperately need money for more research.
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate for the whole of March
pageSummaryWhy: they desperately need money for more research.
story:
As many of you know, on 26th November 2020, my amazing big sister Tracy suddenly and unexpectedly passed away from Hypertensive Heart Failure aged just 54 years. Tracy went to sleep on the evening of 25th November and just never woke up.  Her passing hit the whole family so hard, especially as none of us, including my sister, had any idea she was suffering from heart failure.

Giving up chocolate for a month may not seem the most challenging way to raise money but let me tell you, to a massive chocoholic like myself, this is is the equivalent of a jogger running a marathon! I need to lose a few lbs especially now Boris has said we may be able to socialise in the summer, but also, losing my sister has made me realise I need to get myself a bit fitter and look after myself more.

If you can spare even the smallest amount in aid of BHF, that would be amazing.  The work they do in researching heart problems is phenomenal and I like to think that had we known about my sister's illness, they could potentially have saved or prolonged her life through the work they have done.

Thankyou xx

Love you sis 💔

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

pageSummary: supporting BHF in memory of Norah Smith because she is missed and loved every day.
pageSummaryWhat: supporting BHF in memory of Norah Smith
pageSummaryWhy: she is missed and loved every day.
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge for all of us, and charities are struggling. It has led to BHF being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, they’ve never needed our support more. 

I am thrilled that Mark and our two boys are doing this challenge with me to remember my Mam in such a good way to support the BHF. 

We lost my mam when I was 20 (she was 53).  She never met Mark, she never got to know the joy of  knowing our boys. When he was younger, my eldest once said he missed not knowing what her voice sounded like! (Brought a tear to my eye, I don’t mind telling you). 

Your donation will help so many children know what their grandparents sound like and to have lovely memories of time spent with them. 

Thankyou, Pamela x

pageSummary: I am fundraising because It is very close to us with baileys CHD.
pageSummaryWhy: It is very close to us with baileys CHD.
story:
Hey all, 

I am fundraising for British heart foundation because of our Bailey boo. As some of you are aware, he was diagnosed with a Congenital heart disease when I was 20 weeks pregnant. Along with the worse news and pregnancy, he was born and needed no help but as time went on, he started choking and throwing up and having breathing issues. He went on to have heart surgery at 7 months old which has left him with no pulse in his left arm. He is a heart warrior! He still has a long road ahead of him, but he’s got this 💪🏼


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Edward Baker
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

story:
I am giving up sweets and chocolate for the month of March, for anybody who knows me, you’ll know that’s going to be hard! 

Please help me raise money for the BHF in memory of my Dad and Grandad who both sadly died from heart attacks. BHF need your help to raise funds in this challenging time.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: Chocolate is now my nemesis! I shall defeat you!! because Chocolate is bad! Charity is good!
pageSummaryWhat: Chocolate is now my nemesis! I shall defeat you!!
pageSummaryWhy: Chocolate is bad! Charity is good!
story:
I won’t lie guys, this could possibly be my hardest challenge yet!! I mean I really really really love chocolate, that yummy velvety smooth taste, sneaking eating it whilst my 4year old isn’t looking, delicious!!! ............... oh boy! what have I done :( 

I’d like to say I’m doing this because I’m a good person that loves giving back, but if I’m honest I’m doing this because this lockdown has lead to me comfort eating and chocolate has become BFF! So the thought that I can do a good thing just by giving up something that I really should give up anyway means this is a no brainer!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: The BHF has always been a charity that our family has supported. Their research has meant that both my grandad and my dad have both managed to spend more time with loved ones. Most of you won't know in April 2021 my dad suffered a severe cardiac arrest and the outlook wasn't good and we were told to prepare for the worst. Thankfully my dad pulled through and after some time in intensive care he started to make improvements day by day. He was fitted with a defibrillator and the genetics testing started. It's thanks to research from the BHF that my sister and I were able to get heart scans while we waited to find out if dad could have passed his heart disease to us and we to our kids. Thankfully all results showed it isn't genetic and dad having a defibrillator fitted means he can pretty much live a normal life. Covid has meant that the BHF has lost of funding and therefore I have decided to support them by doing dechox. Giving up chocolate, cakes and sweets is not easy! But it's certainly worth it for the amazing work this charity does. Thank you for taking time to read my story, say a prayer for my husband Ant and any donations are great appreciated. Thank you, Natalie xxx

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: As a family we are raising money
pageSummaryWhat: As a family we are raising money
story:
As a family we are raising money for British heart foundation, a charity close to our heart. ♥️ 

We have chosen to give up chocolate and sweets together (Sam has already given up biscuits and crisps for lent) and Sam and Kim are also cutting down on the wine! 😂

We’re taking part as some of you are already aware our dad (Paul) suffered a heart attack in October 2020, in the mist of a pandemic, at the age of 49, thankfully the NHS did an amazing job and now he’s back to his ‘normal’ self!😂 We’re super proud of him for giving up smoking and as a family have made changes to our diet, not only are we doing this for dad, but in memory of mum's (Sarah) dad who past away in 1986 at the age of 57 of Rheumatic heart disease. 

Any donations are very appreciated! 😊

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story: The sad passing of one of our colleagues has been a shock to us all and may of made us all realise how short life can be. Due to the nature of Sean‘s passing and the support Sean’s family want to provide for the British Heart Foundation the team have decided at MIA Train Station to walk 12,500 steps a day throughout the whole march to raise funds for this worth while cause. Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Giving up beloved chocolate to raise money for BHS because They do outstanding work treating these conditions
pageSummaryWhat: Giving up beloved chocolate to raise money for BHS
pageSummaryWhy: They do outstanding work treating these conditions
story:
I am doing this fundraiser as heart conditions affect so many across Northern Ireland, not least of all my husband Gary who takes medication for a heart condition as a result of serious illness a few years ago and he is also diabetic so the work BHF do is vital to his health and so many others all over the country. Giving up chocolate is a big sacrifice for me as anyone who knows me can confirm! However compared to the suffering of people with complex heart conditions etc it is a small price to pay. Please donate whatever you are able to as BHF and I will be ever, ever so grateful.

Lots of love

Yvonne xx




British Heart Foundation Statement 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
We are today remembering the gift of a lovely lady with a huge heart. 

Instead of flowers for her service please do give to this great charity. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
So for me this is actually going to be incredibly hard! I blooming love chocolate!! So this will be an interesting month.... so any donations would be greatfully received and hopefully will give me the boost to do it!! 

And all donations with help the British heart foundation so much: 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

pageSummary: I'm giving up the sweeeet (and oh so good) stuff because I'd like to raise funds in memory of my nan
pageSummaryWhat: I'm giving up the sweeeet (and oh so good) stuff
pageSummaryWhy: I'd like to raise funds in memory of my nan
story:
I'm totally addicted to sugar. It is my one true love, my achilles heel, my weak point. Not a glass of wine on a Friday night, or a virtual shopping trip. It's the gooeyyyest brownies, the super yum cookies, doughnuts, the large bar of choc that gets me the most. Especially during the past year. 

I've been doing some research on sugar and the science behind what sugar does to your body. It seems that we're all slightly addicted (or worse) because it is basically in everything we eat that can be bought from a box or a packet. I want to set the reset button and see if it can make a difference to the way I feel. I got to a point around 2 years ago when my mental health was at its lowest, where I ate sugar such as chocolate instead of meals. As I have been exploring going booze-free when possible and not smoking when socialising, sugar has stepped up to fill those gaps. To summarise...this is a big challenge for me. 

We sadly lost our Nan recently and although she had a great and full life, she also suffered with heart related issues, she had two strokes and diabetes. To be honest it kinda seems ironic doing this challenge in her memory as she was the biggest cake and biscuit lover of all! But, I think she would have liked the sentiment and I'd really like to raise some money for the charity to honour her and all she did for us during her lifetime. We called her 'Nanny Daniel'. She was my mum's mum and she was a modest, headstrong and independent woman. She always laughed and smiled when you chatted to her. In her later years, she didn't talk too much and I'm not sure if this was related to the strokes she had. Or maybe it was due to a kind of contentment you reach later on in life. When I was young she would take me and my 567 other cousins on the train to the beach and I have no idea why she did that because there were so many of us - it must have been a nightmare haha. She would often go on train trips with our Grandad and bring me back a paper bag of my favourite sweets, 'toothbrushes and teeth'. Oh the nostalgia! And again, the irony. 

As much as I love-d sweets, at the age of 29, I'd like to try something new. For my health and to celebrate the life of our beloved Nanny Daniel, I'm giving up the sweet stuff for 30 days. I'm going to be removing refined sugar from my diet as much as possible, whilst allowing myself small amounts of natural sugar from fruits. 

Things I will not be eating / drinking (and for each thing there is a £5 penalty): chocolate, sweets, cake of any form (doughnuts, cookies, biscuits), fizzy drinks, alcohol, anything that has an obvious amount of refined sugar! I will allow myself bread but will be mindful with how much I eat.

And if you've got this far - thank you for your support!

Bex 

x 

PS please always Gift Aid :) - the charity can claim back 25% of your donation from tax you have paid at no cost to you! It's a no-brainer. 


A lil bit from the British Heart Foundation:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate for the month of March,
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate for the month of March,
story:
Without the BHF and the research they do many people would not be around today. This includes our grandaughter who was born with complex Cronic Heart Disease and has undergone 4 major heart surgeries all before her 4th birthday. After all that she has been through and how well she copes I’m sure I can manage without chocolate for just 31 days. It will be tough but with your support for the charity I am sure I can do it.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. pageSummaryWhat: We’re giving up sweet treats this March
pageSummaryWhy: It’s important to us that research is funded
story:
Last July I had heart surgery to correct an electrical problem with my heart known as Supraventriculartachychardia (SVT). We don’t know whether it has been fixed yet, but It’s only because of research that surgeries like mine have made strides forward to become common place and can help so many people live normal lives. 

Please help me support BHF this month by donating a few pennies  :) 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I have decided to take part in dechox for
pageSummaryWhat: I have decided to take part in dechox for
story:
During the early part of the Pandemic I became sick. One day I just couldn’t walk up the road only a short distance to the post box. I was experiencing pains in my jaw, neck and back. It happened so quickly it was frightening.

Thanks to swift action by my GP, roll on one month, I had been mainly  fixed thanks to the work of the cardiac team at Frimley Park Hospital, Surrey.

Without the  research of the BHF into heart attacks especially for women when it’s very easy to misdiagnose, I’m still here today and probably a bit healthier as a result.  So for the month of March I’m giving up chocolate to support Dechox 2021. Please support if you can. For those of you that know me, you know this isn’t going to be easy!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Raising money because As a volunteer, it is very difficult in these time
pageSummaryWhy: As a volunteer, it is very difficult in these time
story:
As a British Heart Foundation volunteer I am feeling inadequate, as it is not easy to fund raise at the moment ..So when the B.H.F. .decided to make March Dechox month (give up chocolate for the month) I signed up to try and raise some money by not eating chocolate for said month, asking my friends to donate a small amount to the B.H.F.. 

Please donate a small amount, and I promise (though it will be very hard) not to eat chocolate (OR chocolate cake)for all of March.

Please help me with my volunteering.Hilary.

pageSummary: We are taking the de-chocx challenge
pageSummaryWhat: We are taking the de-chocx challenge
story:
As a family, we are taking the de-chox challenge in memory of our Dad and Grandad David Johnson. He was taken from us unexpectedly in 2008 following a heart attack at age 65.

We want to support the BHF by raising money to support research which may help other families avoid such heartbreak. 

Please see the statement below from the charity:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: I am Claire and I am doing my first dechox because I want to help raise funds for vital research
pageSummaryWhat: I am Claire and I am doing my first dechox
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help raise funds for vital research
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation.

Both my parents have had heart problems over the years and most recently my mum had an aortic valve replacement In autumn 2019 at St Bart's hospital London.

 I am thankful for the care they have received over the years and am aware the importance science has in advancing medicine and treatments.

£48  Will fund four hours of scientific research 😊

This may be one of my biggest challenges ever, giving up chocolate for 31 days. 

 I ♥️ Chocolate.

Thank you for taking the time to read and hopefully sponsor me xxxxx

story: The sad passing of one of our colleagues has been a shock to us all and may of made us all realise how short life can be. Due to the nature of Sean‘s passing and the support Sean’s family want to provide for the British Heart Foundation the team have decided at MIA Train Station to walk 12,500 steps a day throughout the whole march to raise funds for this worth while cause. Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

ProfileWhat: Me, Isabelle and Carol are having “no fun March”

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I’m fundraising because I love and miss my brother Dane.
pageSummaryWhy: I love and miss my brother Dane.
story:
As many of my friends know my brother Dane Huddart passed away very suddenly on the morning on the 13th of September 2016 from a virus to the heart muscle called ‘Myocarditis’  causing a cardiac arrest in his sleep.

Losing Dane has had such an affect on me mentally I feel the need that the only way I can get through the challenges life brings us is to raise money in his memory for the BHF.

With the pandemic we haven’t been able to do the usual walks we do or the charity ball for such a long period of time and with Dane’s birthday month being in March itself I feel that this challenge would be very fitting and also fitting for myself as I am an absolute chocoholic/sugaraholic and anyone who knew Dane would know how important it was for him to inspire other people aswell as himself to live a healthy life style. 

He was absolutely right...our health is so so important. 

So I continue to do this for him and would appreciate any support from my family, friends, Dane’s friends or anyone who knows of our family. Please know any donation is always appreciated big or small 🙏🏻❤️

I have set my target this time for £200 I know the first time I did dechox a couple of years ago successfully my target was £100 which went well over so please please anyone and everyone give us a sponsor! 

This is also the kick up the arse I need to stop eating crap, which I know Dane would be immensely proud of. 🙌🏻❤️

Thankyou kindly for reading,


Charlotte
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page for Dane
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Dane Huddart

ProfileWhy: I love and miss my brother Dane.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I have decided to give up chocolate for the month of march to try and raise money for the British heart foundation. 

I am very aware of how fantastic this charity is, supporting people with heart and circulatory diseases, so thought I'd challenge myself to try and raise some penny's for them. 


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story: Heart disease has had huge impact upon my life over the past year. Not only did my loving, caring mum die from it last year, but I have to watch my dad suffer from it during the past year and having to go through some very scary moments with him. I know may not may not be doing the most challenging of challenges, but any contribution towards this worthy will be gratefully appreciated. Thank you

pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate for March because I want to raise money for life changing research.
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate for March
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money for life changing research.
story:
For anyone that knows me, you will know that chocolate is one of my favourite things, from a delicious bar of milk chocolate to a tub of Quality Street, I love them all.

Lockdown has been a great opportunity to indulge in my love of chocolate! But now, enough is enough, I am going cold turkey for March to support this amazing charity in a year that has been devastating for their fund raising.

Anything you can spare would be greatly appreciated as I face into my toughest challenge EVER!!!

pageSummary: I am giving up every single sweet treat ... because ... BHF are a very special charity to me!
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up every single sweet treat ...
pageSummaryWhy: ... BHF are a very special charity to me!
story:
Hi, I'm Immy and I am 15 years old. 

When I was 3 and a half years old, I lost my Daddy to an unknown heart condition. 

This April, my Daddy will have been gone for 12 years, but he will always live on in spirit in my mum and me. 

My Dada was the BEST man and Daddy Ever. He was so kind and caring, and EVERYONE just ADORED him. He is our Angel and he is the brightest star in the sky now, and I know that he always looks after us from Heaven.

Because we don't know the exact details for why my Daddy suddenly died, I am currently under Great Ormond Street Hospital, who take great care of me and always make sure my heart is healthy! 

At the minute, and for about the next three years, I have a heart monitor in me. In the October of 2020, I had a little procedure where GOSH put a loop recorder in my chest, to monitor my heart at all times. 


I miss my Daddy so so sooooooooooooooooo much, and I would absolutely love to raise LOADS of money for the BHF so that no other little girls, or boys, have to go through what happened to my family. 

I love you so much Daddy - You are the best Daddy in the world, and you are forever in my heart and my thoughts. 

I love you.

I miss you.

I look up at the sky at you.

Love from, 

Your Little Princess, 

Imogen xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

pageSummary: Isla, Ava and Sandra are back to do the Dechox because it are such a worthy cause
pageSummaryWhat: Isla, Ava and Sandra are back to do the Dechox
pageSummaryWhy: it are such a worthy cause
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. 

Isla, Ava and Sandra are back to do the Dechox 2021 in support of the British Heart Foundation!

This year we are giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks. We have been overindulging a little throughout seveal lockdowns this past year due to Civid-19.

This is a great opportunity to raise some much needed cash For the BHF, and heres hoping we lose a few pounds along the way!

I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

I want to challenge myself and I have lost people close to me with heart conditions so I’m doing this for them and myself and the British heart foundation is such a great charity to help out. So let’s do this!

story:
In a bid to make my own lifestyle healthier I have decided to get on board with the BHF dechox challenge as a ‘snack leader’ and cut out chocolate as well as sweets and fizzy drinks throughout the month of March. 

Doing this challenge will force me to make healthier lifestyle choices, whilst raising money for a great cause who have been heavily impacted by the covid pandemic.

This charity has always been close to my heart because of my late Grandad. 

Any donations would be hugely appreciated.


Thanks, Jemma xx

For the second year in a row I'm giving up chocolate for March. But this time.. Sweets and fizzy drinks will be cut too. 

Anyone that knows me well enough will know i drink diet fizzy drinks every day without fail. And sweets and chocolate.. Well you don't get to look this rotund without it. 

Please donate. I'd be very grateful.
