The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: Whichs Walk cycle run for sarah
story: Thanks for visiting our team fundraising page. We work for Which? and we are fundraising for the British Heart Foundation in memory of our friend and colleague Sarah Price, who passed away suddenly last year at the age of 39. Sarah was a wonderful person; she excelled in her job but was also a committed team-player, going to great lengths to help her team members day-in, day-out. She was a brilliant friend: funny and kind, someone who always made time for everyone she encountered. We continue to miss her greatly. Sarah was a big fan of Welsh rugby and so we are planning to run, walk or cycle a combined distance that will stretch from our Bristol office, where Sarah worked, to the Principality Stadium in Cardiff and back again, which is around 86 miles in total. We plan to do this over the weekend of 27 - 28 February 2021, being the weekend closest to both St. David's Day and Sarah's 5-year anniversary since she started at Which?. Each participant will undertake 5km, either walking, running or cycling, to help us get to the total distance. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to donations that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us hit our target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Going without chocolate for the whole of March
pageSummaryWhat: Going without chocolate for the whole of March
story:
The British Heart Foundation is an important charity to me as various heart problems have affected my family and still do. BHF needs money from fundraising to help conduct life saving research and support people with heart conditions like my loved ones. Giving up chocolate is a huge thing for me as it's one of my biggest weaknesses! But I need to make this step towards cutting down on unhealthy food and eating them in moderation so that I can secure a healthy future for myself and prevent myself from suffering from preventable conditions.

From BHF:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. pageSummary: I completed this challenge back in 2018 because It is a great way to raise money. Let’s do it agai
pageSummaryWhat: I completed this challenge back in 2018
pageSummaryWhy: It is a great way to raise money. Let’s do it agai
story:
For those who know me... I really enjoy chocolate, especially dark chocolate. I completed this challenge before, back in 2018, and raised £98! It was tough but I did it 💪!

So I thought I would give this challenge ago again, to raise money for this amazing charity! Especially with being in lockdown, it is going to be the BIGGEST challenge yet! 

There is nothing too small to contribute to this amazing cause,  as well as the much needed support I need along the way. I shall keep you all update throughout my challenge. 

Thank you. 

Vee x

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Many people might know the the BHF are raising money by detoxing through March and taking part in Dechox. 

As you all know I love my sweets, chocolate and fizzy drinks.... But I'm giving it all up for 31 days to raise money for the heart foundation. 

I recently went through a heart operation in John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford. They are amazing at their jobs and they have hopefully cured my condition (I find out in 2 months 🤞) 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Back in 2017, very unexpectedly we lost our much loved Dad. Unknowingly, Dad suffered from a rare inflammation of the heart called Myocarditis. Although diagnosing Myocarditis is extremely hard due to the lack of specific symptoms theres is still so much to learn from this horrendous disease to enable any prevention. Due to the pandemic alot of the vital research BHF carry out has been cut. Therefore, it as important as ever to help raise funds to get research back on track. 

During March we are taking part in the Dechox challenge which means no chocolate for the full month. As chocoholics this will definitely be a challenge 🙈. Let's beat heartbreak forever ❤ 


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I am doing this because my beautiful nephew was diagnosed at 20 weeks with Coronary Heart Disease (CHD), I love my little heart warrior to the moon 🌝 and back. He’s such a fighter, here’s a bit of information: Even though we’re facing a huge public health emergency, a baby will still be born with a serious heart condition every 2 hours. That fact remains. As does the fact that we will now need to do even more to protect them, their families, and the health professionals that look after them, over the coming weeks and months.

A note from the British Heart Foundation: The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

pageSummary: I am selling handmade dog Bandanas because I want to raise money to help train puppies!
pageSummaryWhat: I am selling handmade dog Bandanas
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money to help train puppies!
story:
Hi everyone!

Every day 250 people in the UK start to lose their
sight - Guide Dogs are there to make sure they don’t lose their freedom as well. With the help of my Nanny I am making dog bandanas and every penny raised will go towards helping guide dogs provide life changing services for people with sight loss. Recently I have sponsored a puppy guide dog in training (also called Lily!) and give £1 a week of my pocket money! The money you donate will help - 

£13.00 could support a guide dog for a day

£25.00 could pay for an hour of training to help puppies’ change someone’s life

£50.00 could pay for fun; tactical activities to
help children with sight loss coordinate their muscles and movements

Thank you for your support!! Love Lilly xxx

pageSummary: We are raising money because they have supported Adam's dad for 50 years
pageSummaryWhy: they have supported Adam's dad for 50 years
story:
In March 2021, Eric Tuckwell (Adam's dad) will be celebrating 50 years since first getting a Guide Dog. Over that time this wonderful charity has provided him with eight dogs and we want to raise money to allow Guide Dogs to continue to support those with sight loss. 

Throughout the month, Laura, Adam, Joshua, William and Rory will be completing a 500-kilometre challenge. We will be walking, running, cycling, scooting and kayaking a total of 500 kilometres between us. 

Any money raised will make a big difference so on behalf of the five of us, thank you for your donation.

pageSummaryWhy: It is an incredible place of hope and heeling.
story:
It took Frodo 182 days to travel the 1932 miles from Bag End in The Shire to Mount Doom in Mordor, I'm curious to see if I can beat the halfling's time. They say that one does not simply walk into Mordor... well I'm not one to argue with Sean Bean, so I'll be doing it on my bicycle.

Now granted, Frodo travelled by fuzzy foot, takes tiny steps and had to deal with all manner of challenges (from orcs and nazguls, to balrogs and giant spiders), but I work full time as a teacher and am also a very lazy, chubby person... who also has quite fuzzy feet. So I feel this makes us even.

I have until Thursday 26th August 2021 to get to Mordor!

On a serious note, Frodo was a hero. He was selfless and perserveered through the darkest of times facing incredible challenges. He is also fictional, unlike the staff, patients and families of Great Ormand Street who are very real and continue to inspire us with their true bravery and heroism.

This challenge is a bit of silly fun with an eye on staying healthy but if it can help to make a difference to the lives of anyone in need... well that is an adventure worth having!

pageSummary: Rosie and Liv 30 mile total run, bike and walk because We feel we should try to spread awareness❤️
pageSummaryWhat: Rosie and Liv 30 mile total run, bike and walk
pageSummaryWhy: We feel we should try to spread awareness❤️
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Rosie Shipp and Olivia Knight are going to be going 30 miles in total (10 miles run, 10 miles bike and 10 miles walk) for Great Ormond street Children’s Hospice. We will be doing this on the 20th March and will be continuously on the go until we’re finished. 

We are raising money for great Ormond street (Gosh charity) who's mission is to enhance Great Ormond street’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people, giving them the best chance to fulfil their potential.

This charity means a lot to us as we can’t imagine how hard it must be to be a child struggling and in pain! We would love to spread awareness in helping change a life. 

Thank you for Visiting our page and it would mean a lot if you could donate, thank you! ❤️

story:
Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive at GOSH. charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
pageSummary: I am raising much needed funds
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising much needed funds
story:
I’ve done a few triathlons over the years but I’ve never fundraised in the lead up. 

This year is different. 

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Great Ormond Street Hospital GOSH), which see 619 sick kids and young people from across the U.K. arrive every single day, is projecting a loss of £13m.

At the GOSH, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. The GOSH has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to reach their full potential in life.

I started a new job last year which aims to connect children and young people with opportunity. In order to do that, they need to be healthy and well.

So, I’ve decided to use my six month training period, which will culminate with and Olympic Distance Triathlon through the streets of London, to raise funds for the GOSH - where a better future for seriously ill children starts.

Thank you in advance for your generous support and wish me luck on the training front - it's been a minute 🏊‍♀️ 🚲 🏃‍♀️ 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

story: After seeing similar challenges we, Nic, Em, Nic, Kat and Caroline, have decided to challenge ourselves to running, walking or moving 100KM in March. We wanted to do this for Cancer Research, every one of us in some way has been affected in our lives by cancer. Personally, I lost my fabulous father-in-law 2 years ago and the more we can learn about this horrific disease the better. Every charity needs extra support now, thanks to the lack of fundraising being able to take place during the pandemic, so this is our small way to aid them and support the amazing work these charities do. Every penny counts so please donate what you can and we will all look forward to the end of March!! Xx

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are two year six girls who are very good friends. Donating money for cancer research is important to us because Lucy's grandma and grandpa both were diagnosed with Cancer. You donating can help scientists and doctors to get the equipment they need to beat Cancer.

This March, we will be running a mile each day until we reach a marathon (26.2 miles). We will be socially distanced and we will follow government guidelines. We are committed to achieving our goal and we will not give up. Our target is to reach £100 for cancer research.

We chose to do running because it is a great way of keeping healthy and fit, and March is a great time to do running, as the weather is nice and beginning to get warmer.

TOGETHER WE WILL BEAT CANCER!

Thank you,

Lucy and Annabel

pageSummary: I am walking 5k steps a day in March
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking 5k steps a day in March
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This year, I am walking 5k steps every day throughout March (equivalent of around 78 miles) for 2 causes close to my heart. 

Kidney Research: A few years ago, my amazing cousin, Georgia, aged only 17 was diagnosed with kidney failure. Both her kidneys were failing and she needed a transplant as soon as possible. After years of different treatments, time spent at dialysis, blood, sweat and tears, my amazing Uncle, Mike, finally gave her the gift of life last year. I want to raise money for a charity that helped our family and many of other families through this horrible experience.

Cancer Research: Almost a year ago one of my closest and most amazing friends, my second Mam, Dot, was diagnosed with breast cancer. I have lost family members to this horrible disease and I want to do my bit to make sure that in the future, nobody has to go through what Dot has been through this year. 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read my story and for your donations. Every penny means the world. Let’s do this! X

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m Rebecca. I’m a finalist in the Miss Mystic Beauty 2021 pageant. Representing my hometown as Miss Bristol 2021. My platform is anti bullying and suicide prevention awareness. (Mental health) 

I’ve chosen to raise money for Cancer Research UK, because it’s so important to research and provide better understand and hopefully a cure, for such a horrible diagnosis, cancer. 

I personally have anxiety so both nervous and excited for this, as it’s 100% out of my comfort zone.  But a fully important cause worth supporting. 

Just donate here, and you can follow my journey via social media, and my blog. 

Blog: www.Rebeccaklxo.com

Insta: @rebeccaklxo

Myself, Alex Clark and Josh Venney started running together a few weeks back, after a couple of weeks Josh mentioned the idea of running a marathon to which me and Alex agreed. It gave us a goal to work towards during the current lockdown and during the process thought we could try and raise a bit of money for charity. We have chosen cancer research as it has in some way shape or form had an impact on most people’s lives. For me personally it will be 13 years this year that i sadly lost my dad to cancer and less then 2 years since my cousin and his wife lost their little boy Jaxon to it also. I am running this in memory of them. 

I know times are hard for a lot of people at the minute but any donations no matter how small will be greatly appreciated!!

Thanks in advance from all 3 of us!!

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Marie Curie great daffodil appeal Mothers Day prizes.
story:
Wow.... How can we be heading into March already.... This would usually be a busy month for us getting our daffodil pin boxes  out into local shops and with us doing our instore collections at the supermarkets but due to many establishments and shops still closed due to lockdown its not going to be possible.... We will have a few daffy pin boxes in place in some local shops in Huntly and we will notify you where they will be. 

We have decided to do another fantastic lucky square draw for you all to help raise awareness and earn some crucial funds to help care remain in place for those with terminal illness. 

With Mothers day fastly approaching, you have the chance to win some amazing prizes, the Big hamper is worth appx £300 and as if that ain't enough we will have lots of other fab prizes on offer too. Keep checking in on our Facebook page and this event page for prize updates and photos of all on offer! 

The raffle will be drawn on the 13th March to be delivered on that, Its's up to you if you wish to gift it your own mum or simply keep for yourself! Just let us know 😘

I will update the page with photos of what's all on offer over the next few days!

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story: Hello There - I always wanted to do a fundraiser in memory of my late Sister Karen. The Marie Curie "Step into Spring" Fundraiser is such a worthwhile cause and a challenge. I am hoping that during the course of March that one of my family or friends will join me for a walk each day....... at a distance and we will do this in memory of our loved ones  . THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR KIND DONATION. IT IS MUCH APPRECIATED! ...................................................................................................................................................................................................................Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Running a 100 Miles in March for Marie Curie
pageSummary: I have challenged myself to run 100 miles in March because I want to support the care they provide
pageSummaryWhat: I have challenged myself to run 100 miles in March
pageSummaryWhy: I want to support the care they provide
story: When my grandmother was diagnosed with terminal cancer,  my family made the decision to care for her at home. Providing 24 hour care for a loved one is both physically and emotionally challenging. Marie Curie provided us with a lovely lady who would help my grandmother through the night, so we could sleep knowing she had someone by her side. This was a lifeline for my family and we will forever be grateful  for the care and support that was provided. I’m running so I can help another family have this lifeline when they need it most .

pageSummary: Raising money In Memory of my Grandad Eddie because Of the care & love their STARS team gave to him ❤️
pageSummaryWhat: Raising money In Memory of my Grandad Eddie
pageSummaryWhy: Of the care & love their STARS team gave to him ❤️
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

A 300km March challenge in memory of my Grandad ❤️

A Son
A wonderful husband dad and Grandad
A great grandad
A wonderful much loved brother
A treasured uncle to his nephew and Neices
A cousin
A treasured friend
A work colleague
A manager of amateur football
A good neighbour and citizen

 He gave so much and took so little.

Help me to give back to the amazing Marie curie. A special mention to Marie Curie based in Woolton Liverpool and their outstanding Stars team.
We will never forget their devotion 24/7

Coming in & at the very least asking would we like a cup of tea is Simply Special at a time where something so little provided support in more ways that anyone will ever know.... We will never forget. ( Edward Dunn’s Family ) 💙

100% of the money donated will go to Marie Curie UK 🇬🇧

charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: I am joining the Step into Spring challenge because Marie Curie Nurses are so supportive
pageSummaryWhat: I am joining the Step into Spring challenge
pageSummaryWhy: Marie Curie Nurses are so supportive
story: 12 years ago I called Marie Curie nurses twice in the wee small hours to help my mum in her last days  Their presence , sympathetic care of mum and their support for us was a blessing at a very emotional time. Since then I have supported this charity whose nurses give so much in terms of their understanding and care  not only for the dying but also for the family.We were fortunate that mum was allowed to be home amongst those she loved . Marie Curie nurses made that possible. Please hep me help them continue to help others in this situation.. Charity donations make this possible. Thank you

story: This year, Marie Curie daffodil collections cant go ahead, so this year, instead of standing in a supermarket shaking a tin, I will be stepping into spring by walking 10,000 steps a day. Please sponsor me if you can to help support more people affected by terminal illness. Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Name: Walking 10,000 steps a days on wonky knees for Marie Curie Nurses who are angels

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: Walking at least 10,000 steps a day because I'm keeping fit while supporting Marie Curie
pageSummaryWhat: Walking at least 10,000 steps a day
pageSummaryWhy: I'm keeping fit while supporting Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Marie Curie has provided incredible care for someone close to me, and I want to give back this Spring by raising funds to help this amazing charity care for people living with terminal illnesses and provide support to their families.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: I would like to ask donations because the care and support provided to Mel was amazing.
pageSummaryWhat: I would like to ask donations
pageSummaryWhy: the care and support provided to Mel was amazing.
story:
Our nurses, doctors, therapists and social workers provide expert care and support both to the people staying with us at the hospice, and in the local community. 

Each day at the hospice is special. By getting to know people as individuals, we help them do what is important to them  whether thats getting out into the hospice garden to enjoy the views across the sea, having a beloved pet visit come to visit or sharing precious moments with their loved ones.

We need to raise £8,311 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Cardiff and the Vale get the care and support they need.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: 310000 because Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
pageSummaryWhy: Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
For 11 years I have stood out in all weathers collecting for Marie Curie. Sadly this year I can’t do that. So instead I’m going to step up and do 10,000 steps a day. For some this might not be a challenge but for someone who works from home every day and is in lockdown it will take some pushing. So please please sponsor me if you can thank you 😊

Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel.
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk.
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

pageSummary: We are spending the month of March fundraising
pageSummaryWhat: We are spending the month of March fundraising
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. We are so excited to spend the month of March fundraising for Marie Curie, who provide care and support for people living with any terminal illness. They have been working tirelessly on the frontline supporting many people through the pandemic and are in need of our support now more than ever. 

As a team we will be taking part in lots of fundraising events across the month. Kicking off the big 1 million step challenge!! Keep an eye on our socials to see what else we are up to. Please donate as much or as little as you can and help us reach our target. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Over the last year our attention has been heavily focused on the global Covid pandemic but unfortunately cancer hasn’t gone away and now more than ever we need to support the charities that support families through the most difficult of times. 

Personally I spend far too long behind a laptop on a daily basis so I’m looking forward to getting out for a daily walk and raising some money for this fab charity. 

Thanks in advance for the donations!

pageSummary: Helping raise money because I would usually help the Great Daffodil Appeal
pageSummaryWhy: I would usually help the Great Daffodil Appeal
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Normally I would assist Marie Curie with their Great Daffodil Appeal by collecting money in exchange for a daffodil in my local supermarkets. 

However, due to the current climate (COViD) I am unable to do this.

Instead can you please donate here. In addition during the month of march I am planning to knit ear savers and ear warmer if u would like one in exchange for a donation. (Message if you do)

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: walking 10k steps everyday in March because the support given to my Granny was invaluable.
pageSummaryWhy: the support given to my Granny was invaluable.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Marie Curie nurses provided support to my Granny and our family for the last few weeks of her life. This support was very unexpected and something that we won't forget.

The service they provided was fantastic and allowed the family to have some respite throughout the night. 

Granny always loved a walk somewhere therefore I thought it was fitting to walk 10,000 steps per day for the month of March. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
title: March 10k steps per day
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Doreen Govan
Name: March 10k steps per day
ProfileWhy: the support given to my Granny was invaluable.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Throughout March I am going to challenge myself to walk a minimum of 10,000 steps a day every day. So thats a total of 310,000 or more by the end of the month.

Although this is not a lot of steps to some people it is to me. I'm not a active person and I am unfit. But this will enable me to challenge myself and raise money for a good cause at the same time. If you would like to join me and support me in such a great cause.

I'm raising money for Marie Curie and your contribution will make such a impact no matter how big or small.


What will Marie Curie do with the funds raised through Step into Spring i hear you ask?

All fundraising money will go towards supporting the work of Marie Curie Nurses and our other core services. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes across the UK, providing hands-on care and vital emotional support for people living with a terminal illness and those close to them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe.

story:
We are asking for donations to Marie Curie, in memory of our lovely dad, so that we can help them carry on the invaluable work they do.

The Halifax team cared for dad with such love & dignity during his last days.  Nothing was too much trouble and they went above and beyond to make him comfortable and were also there to support us as a family. We shall be forever grateful.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’ve decided to raise money for Marie Curie by walking 10,000 steps a day in March. They offer vital services for people living with a terminal illness and their families. They provide care in hospices across the country and in peoples homes to ensure people get the most from the time they have left. They also provide vital support to friends and families.

It’s a charity that’s close to home for me, it’s been 20 years since they provided care for my Dad in one of their hospices so I thought it was about time I did some fundraising! 

As with everything in the past year a lot of fundraising has been on hold and charity shops have been closed so donations are particularly important right now. 

Any support for the work they do is greatly appreciated 🌼💛

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: 310000 because Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
pageSummaryWhy: Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

eventName: Walking 100 miles or more in March
story:
Me, my mum, sister and of course Teddy, have decided to try and walk 100 miles or more in the month of March to a charity very close to our hearts.

The Marie Curie cared for our granda John, my mums dad in his last hours, they have him nothing but the most comfortable last hours of his life and such amazing care. For this we are forever grateful to them and the amazing work they do.

We don’t have an exact  target,  anything to this amazing charity is appreciated

pageSummary: Adele Sloan is fundraising because My dad,  Fred Bowker’s 80th  Birthday
story:
Thanks for visiting my just giving page.  My dad, Fred was diagnosed with a terminal cancer in August 2020. He was discharged and allowed home to be cared for by his loved ones in his own home.  Given his strength and determination and fight he is thankfully still with us today.  However due to the pandemic my brother and my mum have been the main carers.  It’s been tough, really tough especially so during the night.  Marie Curie been able to send out support to cover a night shift so my brother and mum can rest before they have to get up for the next day.  

My dad marks his 80th birthday on March 14th and it would be great to mark this occasion by running 80KM raising money for Marie Curie who have been able to provide  much needed overnight care for my dad at home and show our appreciation💙 i am going to be running 80km in March (approx 50 miles) If you can donate just a little it would help hugely and show our gratitude and thanks for the  care Marie Curie have and continue to provide  xXx  

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: I am trying 10000 (ish) steps a day in March because In honour of a good friend & great skipper
pageSummaryWhat: I am trying 10000 (ish) steps a day in March
pageSummaryWhy: In honour of a good friend & great skipper
story:
Thank you for any donations - I will be trying to 10000 (ish) steps a day raising money for a great cause in honour of a good friend.  During this time we’ve been on our sofas all day every day so this is a new challenge. Keep an eye for updates !! My trusty four legged friend will be helping me along the way !!! 

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

pageSummary: We have set up this just giving page because it was Marjorie's wish to support this cause.
pageSummaryWhat: We have set up this just giving page
pageSummaryWhy: it was Marjorie's wish to support this cause.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Marjorie Lockwood lost her battle to Covid 19 on the 1st of February 2021. It was her wish that donations be made to the RNLI in her name, after her death. 

As a young married woman, Marjorie collected for the lifeboats, going from door to door delivering envelopes, with her young boys, and then going back a week later to collect donations, giving little cardboard lifeboats to those who were able to donate. It is a charity she felt strongly about up to her last day, leaving instructions in her will for donations to be made to the RNLI.

Marjorie lived up to 90 years of age, passing away just 20 days before her 91st birthday. Up until catching the virus in hospital, she was so full of life and vitality, living independently, and still enjoying her gardening. Those who knew her felt she would live on to collect her telegram from the queen.  

We would like to remember her and celebrate her life in this positive way, and would like others to share in this remembrance by giving what you can, to this very worthy charity. 

Thank you for visiting this page and if you are able to, giving a donation to her chosen charity. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

The RNLI relies on donations from the public to continue saving lives at sea - your donation to this page will help support the running of stations in the South West, including Appledore lifeboat station.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The 3 of us committed to dipping in the North Sea everyday through the winter months (Nov - March) as part of a fund raiser for Marine Conservation. Dedicated and some might say a little bit daft, we have taken ourselves to the beach every day, whatever the weather, and plunged ourselves into the icy sea.  Now that we have entered the final month of this challenge and the North Sea temperature is at its coldest, we would like to raise some money for this extremely worthy charity. Help us to keep dipping through this final chilly month by donating on this page. 

Read more about this worthy charity below:

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together.

story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.

Your support is much appreciated.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

eventName: Tom and Lucie 100 Miles in March
pageSummary: We are raising money because of their work for the animals, seas and forests
pageSummaryWhy: of their work for the animals, seas and forests
story:
Tom Davison and I will be participating in “100 miles in March” to raise money for a fantastic charity WWF 🌍
WWF are tirelessly involved in so many projects around the world to improve wildlife habitats, clean the ocean and more. 🦔 🐳 🦓
100 miles may not sound like a huge challenge but actually for 2 people who work full time, we will have to actually double our daily dog walk length, so it will be quite a challenge for us!!
We are really hoping to raise £200 and we will keep you posted on our progress 😄

This is a selection of the projects WWF are running to help keep our planet amazing.
  • Seafood Top Tips for sustainability 
  • Tomorrow's Tigers.
  • A Trillion Trees.
  • UK SEAS project 
  • Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing.
  • PROTECTING THE YANGTZE FINLESS PORPOISE FOR OVER 15 YEARS.
  • Freshwater conservation.
  • Wildlife conservation in the Amazon.
  • Building sustainable landscapes in the amazon
  • Helping people secure a financial future
  • A water governance observatory for Brazil
  • Better land management in the Mara
And many more 

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

pageSummary: Walking 100 miles in March for WWF because I'm raising money to help stop climate change
pageSummaryWhat: Walking 100 miles in March for WWF
pageSummaryWhy: I'm raising money to help stop climate change
story:
This March I am going to be walking 100 miles to raise money for WWF.

Being in Lockdown has given everyone a lot more free time to worry about things and one thing that's been on my mind a lot is climate change. That's why I want to raise money for WWF who work towards sustainable living, help endangered animals and fight climate change.

Anyone that knows me knows I'm really not a sporty person so this is going to be a challenge but one I'm looking forward to! I am going to track the distance on my Fitbit and will share my progress on social media!

If you could donate and / or share I would be super grateful  ❤️ 🐻🐼🐧🐯 🦁 

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

pageSummary: I am running the Manchester marathon for WWF because It’s time  to give back to nature & animals
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Manchester marathon for WWF
pageSummaryWhy: It’s time  to give back to nature & animals
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

I have always loved animals from a young age and with everything that’s happened in the past year it’s made me grateful to be healthy and happy with my family and my pets. 

I wanted to give back to the world, by protecting the smallest of animals to the biggest. After growing up with so many  animals, I can’t express the joy and love I’ve felt from just the small lives that have blessed me in  my life so far.

Its heartbreaking to see many animals that are becoming extinct, and it’s sad to say this is sometimes from man made causes and because they can’t receive the resources they need to survive or reproduce.

I wanted to be able to give back, or to help save even one life from a threat of extinction or lower quality of life. I think it’s important to cherish and persevere all lives, protecting them as we grow older so they can continue to grow old with us as a race.

If I could help donate and protect just one life across my training and journey to running this marathon, I would do it  a thousand times over.

I’m running for WWF as my chosen charity  and hope to raise as much as I can across the next few months to protect animals across the world.

Anything as little as 1p can help start to save a life, all donations are welcomed, I hope to cherish this time to think about nature and all the animals that live in communion  with us on our planet bettering it each day. 

I hope to complete my run successfully and proud knowing together we have helped better an animals life.

I would appreciate any help with this project and welcome the support alongside listening to any personal stories you have about animals and nature.

Let’s love our planet more x

pageSummary: I am taking part in the Great North Run 🏃‍♀️ because I want to help to save our planet and environment
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in the Great North Run 🏃‍♀️
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help to save our planet and environment
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. 

The clock is ticking to save some amazing species, so in order to support the WWF I will be running the Great North Run this September to raise as much money as I can to help them continue their great work. By donating you’ll be giving money towards some of their great projects such as; training for local communities to live in harmony with Jaguars, firefighting efforts to tackle forest fires, and preventing the loss of Orangutan habitat in Borneo. 

I’ll be training over the next 6 months to prepare for the run. I’ve got a personal target to run it in under 2 hours so need to put in the practice! 

I’ll be posting my training updates so you can see my progress as we get closer to the event. 

We can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated! Find out more about WWF by visiting wwf.org.uk

Go Team Panda! 🐼

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.

Your support is much appreciated.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk
title: Kazuki's page

Name: Kazuki's page

charity.description:
Protecting rainforest is the smartest climate action we can take, no matter where we live. 

That's why Cool Earth works to find the best ways to keep rainforest standing strong by putting the needs and rights of local people first.
charity.name: Cool Earth
story:
Mine and Lizzie’s birthdays are coming up, and for obvious reasons we cannot throw a big knees-up like we did last year. We have somehow managed to convince ourselves that such fun can be replicated by running a lengthy distance for a charitable cause, and that that is a reasonable way to celebrate our birthdays. So on 8th March Lizzie and I will both be running to our cultural homeland, the Monkey Puzzle pub in Paddington, from our new homes which are both pretty far from there. Obviously we can’t actually go into the pub, but it’s symbolic or something. For me the distance will be 21.1 km and for Lizzie it will be 10 km. And whoever donates the most to each of us individually gets to choose a silly hat for us to run in. 

I am running for Cool Earth, a charity that builds partnerships all over the world in order to tackle deforestation, and works with communities to help them to protect the rainforests in which they live: https://www.coolearth.org/what-we-do/ 

Lizzie is running for Women's Aid, a charity who keep people safe by fighting against domestic abuse. This is particularly important at the moment as women in dangerous domestic situations have faced the brunt of coronavirus and restrictions:  https://www.womensaid.org.uk/

Lizzie's justgiving page: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/whoateallthecheesecake

In an ideal world we'd be having a pint (or 2) with you ensemble, so instead we'd be grateful if you could donate the round towards these important causes... (and tick giftaid xoxox) 

THANK YOU!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Climate change is affecting millions of the worlds poorest people, right now. More frequent and extreme weather is destroying homes, and wrecking lives. The people who have done the least to cause the climate emergency are being hit the hardest this is an injustice that can and must be stopped.

Oxfam is protecting families forced to flee their homes, supporting those hit by changing weather, making sure children have a chance of a future free from poverty and responding to the deadly threat of coronavirus. Through all of this, we rely on brilliant supporters like you to make sure our dedicated teams can be where they're needed most. We couldn't do our work without you.

Every donation, no matter how big or small, makes a difference. 

Together, we won't live with poverty.

pageSummary: I'm raising money because they head into danger without counting the cost
pageSummaryWhy: they head into danger without counting the cost
story:
Hello friends. I'm cycling the London to Brighton bike ride this September, 55 miles through rolling English countryside from the capital to the coast. That's 'rolling' as in hilly, which means it's quite challenging in parts, especially for an amateur who doesn't wear head-to-toe Lycra. I think I'm going to enjoy it a lot and find it pretty hard. 

I've been thinking about my mum a lot recently. She died of cancer nearly four years ago. She always wanted to be a doctor, but her parents couldn't afford to send her to medical school. She became an amazing teacher instead, but medicine remained an unfulfilled passion and dream for her. So I think she'd like the fact that I'm raising money for Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF).  

As you probably know, MSF is an amazing global organisation that gets urgent medical help to people in war zones and other emergencies. Its ambulances head right into the thick of it, with doctors and nurses ready to put their own lives on the line to save others. Really brave individuals doing amazing things for people they've never met. 

I was never sporty at school or even as a young adult, so I think Mum would be surprised at how much cycling I've done since we first went into lockdown in March 2020. She would definitely have understood the feeling of freedom that cycling gives me. And I'd have told her that some of my happiest childhood memories are of going out on long bike rides, exploring anywhere I liked and coming back in time for tea. 

My mum was unfailingly supportive of all my adventures and misadventures over the years. She was an incredibly determined person herself. For example, she had polio in her twenties and was told she wouldn't walk again, but walk she did. I guess she taught me never to give up. Thanks, Mum! 

If you'd like to make a donation, I'll really appreciate it. It will give the extra incentive to keep going to the end of the course and it will make a difference to people in life-or-death situations. 

If you don't want to donate, that's totally fine, maybe you can send me a message on the morning of 19 September instead, or email me sometime between now and then telling me to keep on training and not to forget to take lots of water with me this time. That would be equally lovely. 

THANK YOU VERY MUCH for reading this, in any case! Kathy :-)

[Small print: Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your money goes direct to the charity. Even if I were tempted to siphon some off for a celebratory beer at the end of the ride, or indeed a shiny new bike, I couldn't]

charity.description: Malaria No More UK mobilises governments, influencers, businesses and the public to end deaths from malaria and wipe out the disease for good. Our mission is to catalyse and inspire the global partnerships, leadership and financing to make malaria no more in a generation.
charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
pageSummary: I am happy to say that you all will so much happy. because People around the world will be much happy.
pageSummaryWhat: I am happy to say that you all will so much happy.
pageSummaryWhy: People around the world will be much happy.
story: Every two minutes a child under 5 dies from malaria and yet, it is preventable and treatable. Since 2000 we’ve cut world malaria deaths by 60%, but that progress is in jeopardy and we need to step up efforts. By making a donation, you’ll be helping to protect children and their families from malaria, save lives and create a world where no child suffers needlessly. That means more kids in school, more people in work, less pressure on health services. A future with less poverty and more economic growth.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I'm walking 12 km every day in March because clean water should be a norm for everyone
pageSummaryWhat: I'm walking 12 km every day in March
pageSummaryWhy: clean water should be a norm for everyone
story:
Dear Friends! WaterAid is a charity dedicated to making access to clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Millions of women and children around the world walk long distances each day to the water source for their families to survive. For me to make a living, I have to endure a sitting position for hours for most days in a week however I can enjoy the luxury of drinkable water, a working toilet and a hot shower whenever I want! But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated, financially secure, and Communities can thrive.

I encourage you to support WaterAid monthly, but if that's too much, here is the deal: I found out about the Walk for Water challenge last minute but I'm ready to roll! My target is to walk 12 km each day in March. Following your stunning support in 2020, I believe you will join me in this quest too, even if it's just a single small donation for WaterAid!

eventName: Access' Manchester to Madagascar - 5,777 miles for WaterAid!
story:
From Manchester to Madagascar 

From 15th February, well be walking, running, cycling, rowing and swimming to travel the 5,777 miles between Manchester to Madagascar, all in aid of highlighting WaterAid's work in Antenanarivo, Madagascar.

5,777 miles might take us a while to complete, so we are going to compete in two teams and start at each end - one team in Manchester and one team in Madagascar - and the objective is to meet in the middle by Easter, and see who gets there first!

Well be walking, running, cycling, rowing or even swimming (when allowed!) to help contribute individually and virtually to the 5,777 miles we need to complete together. 

The objective is to improve all our wellbeing, get us all out more in the fresh air and away from our computers, and to raise £5,777 for a truly magnificent cause!
title: Access agency's Manchester to Madagascar - 5,777 miles for WaterAid!

But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm joining WaterAid's Walk for Water from 1-31March 2021, walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere.  Around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have a better chance to be healthy. WaterAid installs pumps and taps and improves sanitation. It's simple: clean water saves lives.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This March I'm walking every day to a target of 372km by the end of the month, in support of Water Aid.
I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere.
Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can have the basics of human prosperity.
Please help a little, if you can. <3

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
